Can we please have some unit tests around the celery executor?
@mistercrunch I think these files just need to be excluded from the /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/scripts/ci/check-license.sh check, but I think @bolkedebruin can say for sure.

It was there as it used to be that you would use "N+1" in make files (where N is the amount of cores). So that your would not over commit the cpu while still keeping it busy. With the type of loads airflow generates, often waiting for other remote processes to finish, it indeed might not make sense.
Add the license directory to .rat-excludes, that solves the issue.

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2354?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2354?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [b13cd6d...983fe6c](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2354?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
The commit message should still start with [AIRFLOW-xxxx]
lgtm +1

I think it should be the responsibility the executor to reschedule tasks to run, with no "special" message passing between task instance run function and executors like sys.exist(EBUSY) (the task should just record it's state in the DB and the executor should use that to determine what to do with the task). Couldn't the job see that the state was None after running the task and reschedule appropriately?

I'm seeing the flow as something like this 
Job -> Executor -> TI.run()
The executor will facilitate the running of the airflow command to run to completion without knowing anything about the task itself or communicating with the Airflow DB. It should be quite dumb. It will be the responsibility of the job to e.g. check TI state is none and re-send it to an executor.

Am I completely off here?

The current logic is Job -> Executor -> LocalTaskJob -> TI.Run. 

We have Executor and LocalTaskJob to monitor the execution of tasks. You need this kind of logic to guard against tasks that are not able to set themselves to a certain state, e.g. out of memory, sigkill, segfault etc (which are set by the os). Thus here you cannot count on what the state of the TaskInstance is.

As we are executing the tasks as subprocesses and cannot just rely on what the task reports as its state, we will need to rely on how the OS passes messages (errors in this case) between the processes it runs. 

In backfills we are relying on the monitoring (already in 1.7.x) to verify that what the task is reporting as state in congruent with what the executor is thinking the task can report at all. The need for CONCURRENCY_REACHED/EBUSY is to make sure the executor and the task stay in sync. Otherwise the executor would report either success or failed which would not make sense in case of State.NONE (or any other state that does not signal SUCCESS or FAILED). I didn't add CONCURRENCY_REACHED to the task states as that would requiring the Scheduler code to handle that as well. I tried to keep the changes to a minimum.

Obviously I am open to a more simple approach, given the constraints of monitoring. I tried a couple of approaches (removing the TI from the tasks the executor knows when reporting about which was a hack and didn't work), but I ended up with tasks being marked failed incorrectly every single time.

@aoen on your remark that the executor should reschedule tasks I don't think that is smart: it would need its own scheduling logic (backoffs, not scheduling etc). Seems to me as that would severely increase complexity. The executor is quite dumb right now, it just reports back (it already was!) what the OS reports.

Forgot to mention that when I was not using this new executor state I ended up in all kinds Race conditions: the state of the task could already have changed to queued before the executor was able to report back.
